metadata.title: A way to realize controllable preparation of active nickel oxide supported nano-Au catalyst for CO oxidation

Fig. 1 The total oxidation temperature of carbon monoxide vs the chlorine concentration of the aqueous solution containing the catalyst precursors from which the catalyst samples were prepared. 17 catalyst samples prepared parallel from several batches. (a) Au/NiOx-72ppm. The conversion of CO was 15% at 65°C; (b) Au/NiOx-108. The conversion of CO was 13% at 65°C. Fig. 2 N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms and the pore size distributions of Au/NiOx (a) Au/NiOx-2, (b) Au/NiOx-5 and (c) Au/NiOx-24. Fig. 3 XRD patterns of Au/NiOx catalysts. Fig. 4 XPS spectra of Au4f (a) and Ni2p (b) of Au/NiOx catalysts. Fig. 5 FT-IR spectra of the catalysts Au/NiOx-2 (a), Au/NiOx-5 (b) and Au/NiOx-24 (c). Fig. 6 Typical HAADF-STEM images and particle size distributions of catalysts Au/NiOx-2 (a), Au/NiOx-5 (b) and Au/NiOx-24 (c). Fig. 7 Fourier transformed (FT) spectra of Au LIII-edge (a) and Ni k-edge (b) EXAFS for samples Au/NiOx-2, Au/NiOx-5 and Au/NiOx-24. Table 1 Physicochemical properties of catalyst samples. A way to realize controllable preparation of active nickel oxide supported nano-Au catalyst for CO oxidation Chengming Zhang a b Xinjiang Cui a Huimin Yang a b Lirong Zheng c Youquan Deng a Feng Shi a ⁎ a State Key Laboratory for Oxo Synthesis and Selective Oxidation, Centre for Green Chemistry and Catalysis, Lanzhou Institute of Chemical Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Lanzhou 730000, China State Key Laboratory for Oxo Synthesis and Selective Oxidation, Centre for Green Chemistry and Catalysis, Lanzhou Institute of Chemical Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences Lanzhou 730000 China b University of the Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing 100049, China University of the Chinese Academy of Sciences Beijing 100049 China c Center for Multi-disciplinary Research, Institute of High Energy Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing 100049, China Center for Multi-disciplinary Research, Institute of High Energy Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences Beijing 100049 China ⁎ Corresponding author. Tel.: +86 931 4968142. Graphical abstract It was generally accepted that the total elimination of chlorine is favorable to build active supported nano-gold catalysts if chlorine-containing precursors was used especially for the total oxidation of CO. Here a series of Au/NiOx catalysts were prepared with co-precipitation method by tracing the chlorine concentration in the washing step and tested by the total oxidation of CO. It was revealed that Au/NiOx catalysts prepared from aqueous solutions with 4–8ppm chlorine can be active catalysts and the temperature for CO total oxidation was <0°C. The catalytic activity dropped sharply if the chlorine concentration was <4ppm or >8ppm. The catalysts were characterized by XRD, XPS, BET, TEM, HAADF-STEM and EXAFS, and the catalyst structures were explored. The different structures of the catalysts should be responsible for the activity variation and it was caused by the washing operation or the presence of different amounts of chlorine. Although active Au/NiOx catalysts can be obtained by tracing chlorine concentration, the role of chlorine in the fabrication of active nano-gold catalyst was still unclear. Keywords Chlorine concentration CO oxidation Nano-Au catalyst Heterogeneous catalyst Controllable preparation 1 Introduction Since the superior performance of supported nano-Au catalysts for low-temperature CO oxidation was discovered, nano-Au catalysis has attracted persistent attentions and great progress has been made [1–5]. Despite the efforts for the investigation of the potential performance, the exploration of the active-site of nano-Au catalysts and the way to realize controllable preparation of active nano-Au catalysts are always the focuses in nano-Au catalysis for CO total oxidation. In the past decades, it has been revealed that the interface between gold nano-particle and the support is regarded as the active sites and the quantum size effect is an important factor to result in the exceptional activity [6,7]. Furthermore, it has been proved that the amount of active oxygen species is linearly related to the number of perimeter sites at the interface of support and the gold nano-particles [8,9]. Additionally, some research groups agreed that cationic Au attributes the generation of active sites [10–17]. Usually, reducible oxide supports such as Fe2O3 and NiO are also helpful to obtain active nano-gold catalysts for CO and H2 oxidation [18–21]. Xu showed that NiO surface structures in the “NiO-on-Au” inverse catalysts not only enhance Au-catalyzed CO oxidation performance but also prevent sintering of Au nanoparticles at elevated temperatures [22]. About the method for preparation of active nano-Au catalysts, it was well accepted that suitable catalyst precursors, suitable bases for co-precipitation under suitable pH value, complete removing of chlorine in the washing step, and aging and calcining the precipitate at suitable temperature were crucial [1,12–14,23–26]. However, the controllable preparation is still difficult to be realized even follow these rules. Clearly, in the above factors, the removing of chlorine in the washing step is the sole uncontrollable operation because silver nitrate solution is often being used as the detector for chlorine. Inspired by the former report that single Au(111) exhibits good catalytic performance in styrene oxidation in the presence of chlorine [27], we think possibly the controllable preparation of active nano-Au catalyst can be realized by finely tracing the concentration of chlorine. Exactly, through the exploration of Au/Fe2O3 preparation for CO total oxidation with co-precipitation method, we proved that the activity of Au/Fe2O3 catalyst for CO oxidation varied with the chlorine concentration in the aqueous solution containing the catalyst precursors. The catalytic activity for CO oxidation reached the maximum at a range of 1–3ppm chlorine concentration [28]. Accordingly, we speculate that this rule may be also applicable to the preparation of other active nano-Au catalysts. In this work, CO oxidation was used as a model reaction to investigate whether the activity of Au/NiOx catalyst can also be tuned by tracing the chlorine concentration of the catalyst precursor solutions. A series of Au/NiOx catalysts were prepared with co-precipitation method and to our delight, active Au/NiOx catalysts for CO oxidation can be obtained when the chlorine concentrations are in the range of 4–8ppm while less active catalysts will be obtained if derivate this range. 2 Experimental 2.1 Au/NiOx catalyst preparation 20mL Ni(NO3)3·6H2O (0.011M) and 1.05mL HAuCl4 (1g/10mL H2O) were mixed together and were dropwise added into 60mL Na2CO3 solution (0.31M) under vigorous stirring in 0.5h. It was further stirred for 3h, ultrasonically washed for 0.5h and ∼100mL turbid liquid was obtained. The turbid liquid was divided into four sections and separation by centrifugation (8000rpm, 10min). One section of the recovered precipitate was re-dispersed in 160mL deionized water and ultrasonically washed for 1h. The chlorine concentration in the aqueous solution was 5.0ppm determined by potentialstatic scanning method with a CHI660D electrochemical workstation. Then, the solid was separated by centrifugation, dried at 80°C for 3h and calcined at 350°C for 0.5h to produce the catalyst sample, which was denoted as Au/NiOx-5. By varying the quantity of water used in the washing step, a series of Au/NiOx-Y samples were obtained, in which Y suggested the chlorine concentration in ppm. For the purpose of comparison, all the batches were performed under strictly controlled conditions and the only difference in all the catalyst samples was the quantity of water used for washing. 2.2 Low-temperature CO total oxidation CO total oxidation activity measurements were carried out in a fixed-bed reactor at atmospheric pressure with 80mg catalyst. The feed gas was ∼1vol% CO balanced with air (without further purification). The space velocity of the measurement was 15,000h−1. The concentrations of CO and O2 in the effluent gas were analyzed on-line by a gas chromatograph equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD) using Ar as carrier gas. The conversion of CO was calculated from the change in CO concentration between the inlet and outlet gases. 2.3 Chlorine measurement The chloride ion concentration was tested at 25.0°C through potentialstatic scanning on a CHI660D electrochemical workstation. A chloride ion electrode was used as a working electrode and a platinum wire and an Ag/AgCl electrode were used as counter and reference electrodes respectively. Before analysis, a series of Cl-ion standard solutions including 2.0ppm, 4.0ppm, 8.0ppm, 40.0ppm, 200.0ppm and 400.0ppm were prepared using NaCl as the Cl-ion source. The potentialstatic scanning was carried out at interval of 0.1s for 400s in the standard solutions. The system was calibrated with a 5.0ppm standard solution before measurement. The test limit about this method is ∼1ppm. 2.4 Catalyst characterization TEM and HAADF-STEM analysis were carried out on a Tecnai-G2-F30 field emission transmission electron microscope. The catalyst samples were dispersed in ethanol and ultrasonicated at room temperature for 0.5h. A part of solution was dropped on the grid for the measurement of TEM images. XRD measurements are conducted by an X’Pert PRO (PANalytical) diffractometer. The XRD diffraction patterns were scanned in the 2θ range of 10–80°. The XPS measurements were performed with a Thermo scientific ESCALAB 250 instrument provided with a dual Mg/Al anode X-ray source, a hemispherical capacitor analyzer and a 5keV Ar+ ion-gun. All spectra were recorded using non-monochromatic Mg Kα (1253.6eV) radiation. The FT-IR spectra were measured with a Nicolet 5700 spectrometer. Nitrogen adsorption–desorption isotherms were measured at 77K using Micromeritics 2010 instrument. The pore-size distribution was calculated by Barrett, Joyner and Halenda (BJH) method from desorption isotherm. The Au loadings of the catalysts were measured by inductively coupled plasma-atomic emission spectrometry (ICP-AES), using an Iris advantage Thermo Jarrel Ash device. Extended X-ray ab-sorption fine structure (EXAFS) experiments were performed at the Beijing Synchrotron Radiation Facility (BSRF) in Beijing Institute of High Energy Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences with storage ring energy of 2.5GeV and a beam current between 150 and 250mA. The Au LIII edge absorbance of powder catalysts was measured in transmission geometry at room temperature. The energy was scanned from 2200eV below to 1000eV above the Au LIII edge (11,919eV). EXAFS data analysis was carried out using ifeffit analysis programs (http://cars9.uchicago.edu/ifeffit/). Radial distribution functions were obtained by Fourier-transformed k 3-weighted χ function. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Results of CO total oxidation with Au/NiOx catalysts The catalytic activities of 17 Au/NiOx samples, which were prepared from aqueous solutions with chlorine concentrations in the range of 2–108ppm, for the total oxidation of carbon monoxide were studied. Clearly, the catalytic activity of Au/NiOx varied with the changing of chlorine concentration. According to the results shown in Fig. 1 , the CO conversions were lower than 15% if the catalysts were prepared from aqueous solutions containing >70ppm chlorine. The first turning point appeared when the final chlorine concentration was at ∼20ppm. Then more active catalyst was produced when the chlorine concentrations were further going down. The Au/NiOx catalyst with the highest catalytic activity was prepared from aqueous solutions containing ∼5ppm chlorine, with which the CO can be totally oxidized at −6°C. Interestingly, the catalysts turned less active again when the chlorine concentrations were <4ppm. Typically, the CO total oxidation temperature was ∼50°C with catalyst Au/NiOx-1.6. The variation of the catalytic activity is exactly strange. It is widely accepted that the presence of chlorine would result in deactivation of nano-Au catalyst while it is unclear what caused the deactivation when more water was used in the washing step. 3.2 Catalyst characterization and discussion In order to check the relationship among the catalyst preparation operation, catalyst structure and catalytic activity, three typical catalyst samples including Au/NiOx-2, Au/NiOx-5 and Au/NiOx-24, with which the temperatures for CO total oxidation were 35, −6 and 55°C, were characterized by ICP, BET, XRD, XPS, FT-IR, TEM, HAADF-STEM and EXAFS. ICP analysis suggested that the gold loadings in these samples are 2.94wt%, 3.13wt% and 3.03wt%, Table 1 , which suggested that the catalytic activity variation was not caused by gold loading. The results of BET analysis for catalysts Au/NiOx-2, Au/NiOx-5 and Au/NiOx-24 were summarized in Table 1 and Fig. 2 . First, the N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms and the pore size distributions showed that the catalyst samples were all mesoporous materials. The BET surface areas of catalysts Au/NiOx-2, Au/NiOx-5 and Au/NiOx-24 were 252m2/g, 236m2/g and 231m2/g, which suggested that the washing operation or the changing of chlorine concentration did not influence the surface areas of the catalyst samples significantly. In reverse, the N2 adsorption quantity, which were 250, 378 and 482mL/g, and the pore size, which were 4.8, 8.2 and 11.6nm, decreased remarkably if the catalysts were washed with more water. So, although the changing of the amount of water for washing or chlorine concentration in aqueous solution definitely influenced the structure of Au/NiOx remarkably, it cannot explain the catalytic activity difference of the catalysts. The best performance was observed with catalyst Au/NiOx-5 but this catalyst did not possess the highest BET surface, N2 adsorption and average pore size. The X-ray diffraction patterns of the Au/NiOx catalysts were given in Fig. 3 . All the catalyst samples have similar structures and the lattice planes for NiO (111), (200), (220), (311) and (222) [29] were all observable in samples Au/NiOx-2, Au/NiOx-5 and Au/NiOx-24 (JCPDS No. 75-0197). Additionally, there was no observable peak for gold crystal, which suggested that gold species were highly dispersed on the support, or the peak of Au (111) was overlapped with NiO (111). The results were confirmed by XPS characterization. According to the XPS spectra shown in Fig. 4 , the Au4f7/2 peaks were all ∼84.4eV, which were higher than the standard metallic binding energy, i.e. 83.8–84.0eV [17,30]. It suggested that gold species in the catalyst samples should be metallic gold but highly dispersed on nickel oxide support, which was in agreement with the observation from XRD diffraction patterns. Typical Ni2p XPS spectra of NiO were observable and the binding energy of Ni2p3/2 was 854.6eV [31]. In addition, no Na species was observable in all the three samples by XPS. So we imagine that the residual sodium should not be responsible for the different catalytic activity, too. Hydroxyl groups play an important role in the process of CO oxidation [32–34]. It is necessary to investigate whether hydroxyl groups in the three samples result in the difference of reactivity. In order to exclude any occasionality, the catalysts samples were characterized 4 times and similar results were obtained. The typical FT-IR spectra were given in Fig. 5 . Commonly, the broad and strong peak located in 3200–3500cm−1 are assigned to the stretching vibration of hydroxyls and the peak at 1630cm−1 is attributed to the deformation vibration of adsorbed water. The strength of these two peaks is similar in the three samples, which suggest that the difference of activity of the three samples do not rise from the surface hydroxyl groups. Moreover, the peaks at 1380cm−1 and 1464cm−1 correspond to the different vibration mode of carbonates [35,36]. As for Au/NiOx-24, the intensive and sharp peak at 1380cm−1 is probably assigned to nitrate [37]. So possibly the catalyst sample prepared with less washing times containing more nitrate in the final catalyst. However, in consideration of the low activity of Au/NiOx-2, the presence of nitrate should also not the reason for the low activity. Then, the catalysts were characterized by TEM, HR-TEM and HAADF-STEM, Fig. 6 . The TEM characterizations suggested that the structures of the catalysts were similar and the particle sizes of the nano-Au were all ∼2–5nm. Although the HR-TEM characterization showed quite different structures of catalysts Au/NiOx-2, Au/NiOx-5 and Au/NiOx-24, we cannot find out detailed structure of nano-Au particle or nickel oxide support itself. Due to the similar crystal structure of gold and nickel oxide, it is difficult to differentiate between the two varieties. For example, the lattice distance of Au (111) is 0.235–0.236nm and it is 0.241nm for NiO (111). In order to compare the nano-Au particle size distributions in different samples clearer, the catalysts were further characterized by HAADF-STEM. The results suggested that the mean diameters of Au particles in samples Au/NiOx-2, Au/NiOx-5 and Au/NiOx-24 were 5.91, 4.81 and 8.54nm with 2.12, 1.56 and 3.72 standard deviations. So possibly the chlorine concentration or the washing operation influences nano-Au particle significantly and finally catalysts with different activities were obtained. Following, EXAFS characterization was performed to check the structure of Au/NiOx-2, Au/NiOx-5 and Au/NiOx-24 (Tables 2 and 3 and Fig. 7 ). According to the radial distribution functions of Au LIII-edge obtained by Fourier Transformation (FT), similar EXAFS spectra were obtained from samples Au/NiOx-2, Au/NiOx-5 and Au/NiOx-24. Comparing to the Au LIII-edge spectra of standard samples of gold foil, gold oxide and gold chloride, it can be concluded that there is no obvious Au–Cl coordination in all the samples and almost the same spectra as the gold foil were obtained. Therefore, the major gold species are metallic gold [38,39], which confirms the results of XPS characterization. Moreover, only Au–Au coordination was observed and the results were given in Table 2. The Au–Au coordination numbers in samples Au/NiOx-2, Au/NiOx-5 and Au/NiOx-24 were 5.30, 7.66 and 8.38, respectively. So Au/NiOx catalysts prepared from aqueous solutions with high chlorine concentration will result in more metallic gold, which coordination number would go closing the gold foil. If taking their catalytic performance into consideration, it can be partially concluded that Au atoms with suitable coordination numbers would be more active. Different results were obtained from the Ni k-edge EXAFS spectra. The Ni–Ni coordination number [20,22] in sample Au/NiOx-5 is 9.84, which was closer to the nickel oxide sample, i.e. 9.96, while the numbers were 8.58 and 9.24 in samples Au/NiOx-2 and Au/NiOx-24. So nickel atoms in nickel oxide with big coordination numbers are possibly more suitable for active structure construction. Therefore, we speculate that the suitable coordination environment of Au–Au, Ni–Ni and Ni–O might also be one of the important factors to gain active catalysts. 4 Conclusions In summary, by tracing the chlorine concentrations in the aqueous solution, active Au/NiOx catalyst was prepared for CO oxidation reaction. Better catalytic performance can be obtained if the chlorine concentration was in the range of 4–8ppm, otherwise the catalytic activity would drop dramatically. Although active Au/NiOx catalyst can be prepared by tracing the chlorine concentration, it cannot be determined is the chlorine or the washing operation responsible for the catalytic activity variation. This work promotes the exploration of controllable preparation of active nano-Au catalyst and the real role of chlorine in this process is under studying. coredata.dc:description: It was generally accepted that the total elimination of chlorine is favorable to build active supported nano-gold catalysts if chlorine-containing precursors was used especially for the total oxidation of CO. Here a series of Au/NiOx catalysts were prepared with co-precipitation method by tracing the chlorine concentration in the washing step and tested by the total oxidation of CO. It was revealed that Au/NiOx catalysts prepared from aqueous solutions with 4–8ppm chlorine can be active catalysts and the temperature for CO total oxidation was <0°C. The catalytic activity dropped sharply if the chlorine concentration was <4ppm or >8ppm. The catalysts were characterized by XRD, XPS, BET, TEM, HAADF-STEM and EXAFS, and the catalyst structures were explored. The different structures of the catalysts should be responsible for the activity variation and it was caused by the washing operation or the presence of different amounts of chlorine. Although active Au/NiOx catalysts can be obtained by tracing chlorine concentration, the role of chlorine in the fabrication of active nano-gold catalyst was still unclear.
coredata.dc:title: A way to realize controllable preparation of active nickel oxide supported nano-Au catalyst for CO oxidation
